abstract.text: Objectives: In late December, 2019, an outbreak of coronavirus disease in Wuhan, China was caused by a novel coronavirus, newly named severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). We aimed to quantify severity of COVID-19 infection on High-Resolution CT and to determine its relationship with clinical parameters. Materials and Methods: From Jan 11, 2020, to Feb 5, 2020, the clinical, laboratory and HRCT features of 42 patients (26-75 years, 25 males) with COVID-19 were analyzed. The initial and follow-up CT obtained a mean of 4.5 days and 11.6 days from the illness onset were retrospectively assessed for the severity and progression of pneumonia. Correlations among clinical parameters, initial CT features and progression of opacifications were evaluated with Spearman correlation and linear regression analysis. Results: Thirty-five (83%) patients exhibited a progressive process according to CT features during the early stage from onset. Follow-up CT findings showed progressive opacifications, consolidation, interstitial thickening, fibrous strips and air bronchograms, compared to initial CT (all p<0.05). Before regular treatments, there was a moderate correlation between the days from onset and sum score of opacifications (R=0.68, p<0.01). The C-reactive protein, erythrocyte sedimentation rate and lactate dehydrogenase showed significantly positive correlation with the severity of pneumonia assessed on initial CT (R range 0.36-0.75, p<0.05). The highest temperature and the severity of opacifications assessed on initial CT were significantly related to the progression of opacifications on follow-up CT (p=0.001-0.04). Conclusions: Patients with the COVID-19 infection usually presented with typical ground-grass opacities and other CT features, which showed significant correlations with some clinical and laboratory measurements. Follow-up CT images often demonstrated progressions during the early stage from illness onset. Powered by Editorial Manager® and ProduXion Manager® from Aries Systems Corporation Dear Professor Val M. Runge, We are submitting our manuscript entitled "Clinical and High-Resolution CT Features of the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) Pneumonia: Comparison of the Initial and Follow-up Changes" for consideration for publication in your prestigious journal. All the authors have contributed at the different stages of the study, and the study was conducted in accordance with the regulations of our institution. An outbreak of COVID-19 infection began in late Dec, 2019 in Wuhan, until today, the confirmed cases in China has exceeded 76,000. As the top hospital in Wuhan, our institution has admitted almost 2000 confirmed cases till now. Here we enrolled 42 early confirmed cases with intact clinical and follow-up CTs, and studied their clinical, CT features of the SARS-CoV-2 pneumonia as well as their connections.

We believe that the material presented in this manuscript complements the aims and scope of Investigative Radiology; we also believe it is of clinical significance and will be of interest to the readers of Investigative Radiology. It would be tough for one group to complete this task in a short time, including data collection, image review and analysis and manuscript editing. We would also like to bring to your kindly attention that this work was conducted between two research groups with equal contributions.
We would like to be allowed that Dr. Li and Dr. Zhu can share the co-corresponding authorship, as an exception to an extraordinary period of SARS-CoV-2 pneumonia.
We thank you and your reviewers for your efforts and we are looking forward to hearing

We would like to thank the reviewers for their thorough review and thoughtful comments. We have worked rigorously on responding to all comments and have modified and revised the resubmitted manuscript. Please find our point-by-point responses below. Comments are in italics and answers in standard font, changes made in the manuscript are highlighted in yellow both in the response letter and the annotated manuscript.

Reviewer: 1 R 1.1: In this submission to Investigative Radiology the authors analyzed severe cases of COVID-19 in terms of clinical symptoms, laboratory and monitoring results as well as imaging findings depicted on chest CT, particularly with regard to differences between early and late stage of the disease. The paper will provide new knowledge in this topic as identifying risk factors for a severe course of COVID-19 in an early stage may have marked influence on the therapy and outcome of the patients.

We checked and accepted each grammatical change, and carefully changed data/numbers in the text and tables to a meaningful number of digits as suggested. We hope to have satisfactorily addressed and answered to all your comments in our revision. R 2.1: Title: "SARS-CoV-2": Make sure that the very latest correct terminology is used.

Author response 2.1: On February 11 th 2020, WHO announced "Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" as the name of this new disease (previously known as "2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV)"), and International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) announced "severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2)" as the name of the new virus that caused this disease. We replaced the terminology of SARS-CoV-2 pneumonia with the more widely used COVID-19 in the revised manuscript. International Committee on Taxonomy Author response 2.2: Thank you for your comment to improve clarity. At the early period of epidemic, nucleic acid testing for the diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 infection had not yet been available for all the suspected patients. Recent publications pointed out that RT-PCR testing for SARS-CoV-2 nucleic acid may be falsely negative due to immature development of detection technology or improper clinical sampling. We have included as many patients as possible with a confirmed diagnosis of COVID-19 at the time of data collection. As addressed in the Patients part of M&M, those patients with history of lung tumors, surgeries or any of the other common causes of pneumonia (such as influenza virus, adenovirus, respiratory syncytial virus, cytomegalovirus; streptococcus pneumoniae, mycoplasma pneumoniae, chlamydia pneumoniae) were excluded. To make sure that all the clinical, laboratory data and CT images were available, we finally included 42 hospitalized patients. There might be a Berkson bias, Neyman bias or Qetection signal bias. Accordingly, we discussed this inclusion issue as a limitation. Their diagnosis of COVID-19 infection was confirmed with a positive result to real-time fluorescence polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay for SARS-CoV-2 nucleic acid, with nasopharyngeal or oropharyngeal swab specimens. Cases with lung surgery, lung tumors history or any of the other causes of pneumonia from common bacterial and viral pathogens were excluded.

FIGREF20.text: This study has some limitations. First, this is a modest-sized case series of patients287 admitted to the hospital. At the time of data collection, nucleic acid tests for the diagnosis 288 of COVID-19 had not yet been available for all the suspected patients and the detection 289 rate of RT-PCR nucleic acid tests was not high (12, 13). Besides, we only included 290 hospitalized patients with follow-up CT exams to ensure more information on clinical and 291 CT characteristics. Possible selection bias should be noted and further study of a larger 292 cohort is required to obtain a definitive answer. Collection of a larger cohort would help 293 to better define the clinical presentation and imaging features. Second, the quantitative 294 and semi-quantitative methods for measuring the pulmonary lesions may have certain 295 subjectivity. Third, the susceptibility of COVID-19 was considered (initially and 296 incorrectly) to be very low among infants, children and adolescents, so we didn't 297 retrospectively study these groups. More effort should be made to identify the clinical and 298 imaging features in these groups in future studies. 299 In conclusion, the results of this study confirmed that chest CT is important in the 300 diagnosis and management of the COVID-19 infection. Despite meticulous treatments, 301 most patients demonstrated progressions in the early stage from illness onset, according 302 to the follow-up CT examinations. Our clinical and radiologic study findings show that 303 CRP, ESR and LDH level positively correlate with the severity of lung abnormalities 304 quantified on initial CT; moreover, high fever is associated with an adverse follow-up CT 305 outcome, which may add a further facet in the understanding of the clinical expression of 306 this new outbreak. Being familiarized with the clinical and CT features and the early 307 changes of the COVID-19 infection, is of paramount importance.

In a previous study of convalescent patients after SARS, thin-section CT scores for GGO or interstitial opacities were found to be correlated with neutrophil count, CRP and LDH level (28).Guan et al. (29)  detected that severe cases of COVID-19 prominently had elevated levels of CRP (≥10 mg/L) (81.5% vs 56.4%, p<0.001) and LDH (≥250U/L) (58.1% vs 37.2%, p<0.001) as compared with non-severe cases.A multicenter study of clinical characteristics in 1099 patients with laboratoryconfirmed COVID-19 highlighted that the surveillance case definition should not heavily focus on fever detection, considering only 43.8% of patients had fever on initial any abnormalities on initial CT, but were positively associated with progression of the opacification on follow-up CT (mean 7 days after initial CT). These findings indicate that high fever on initial presentation is a potential risk factor of adverse CT outcomes over a short-term follow-up, however the limited cases in this study should be noted. Moreover, several initial CT findings, including sum score and max score for opacification severity as well as area of the max lesion in cross-section, were inversely associated with Δ Sum.A possible explanation for these results may be that patients with relatively serious pulmonary opacities on initial CT have already progressed and then there was a short plateau stage or a gradual decrease trend in abnormalities (14, 30).This study has some limitations. First, this is a modest-sized case series of patients admitted to the hospital. At the time of data collection, nucleic acid tests for the diagnosis of COVID-19 had not yet been available for all the suspected patients and the detection rate of RT-PCR nucleic acid tests was not high (12, 13). Besides, we only included hospitalized patients with follow-up CT exams to ensure more information on clinical and CT characteristics. Possible selection bias should be noted and further study of a larger cohort is required to obtain a definitive answer. Second, the quantitative and semiquantitative methods for measuring the pulmonary lesions may have certain subjectivity.Third, the susceptibility of COVID-19 was considered (initially and incorrectly) to be very low among infants, children and adolescents, so we didn't retrospectively study these groups. More effort should be made to identify the clinical and imaging features in these groups in future studies.In conclusion, the results of this study confirmed that chest CT is important in thediagnosis and management of the COVID-19 infection. Despite meticulous treatments, most patients demonstrated progressions in the early stage from illness onset, according to the follow-up CT examinations. Our clinical and radiologic study findings show that CRP, ESR and LDH level positively correlate with the severity of lung abnormalities quantified on initial CT; moreover, high fever is associated with an adverse follow-up CT outcome, which may add a further facet in the understanding of the clinical expression of this new outbreak. Being familiarized with the clinical and CT features and the early changes of the COVID-19 infection, is of paramount importance.
